August 2020.title: Lyfe Languages Project
August 2020.body:
Hello HPO community,

A great project is underway to translate HPO to and from indigenous lanuages. Please make sure you have a look at the Lyfe Languages Project!

Regards,

The HPO Team.

August 2020.title: HPO Web Application 1.7.0
August 2020.body:
We are happy to announce we have released hpo-web 1.7.0 over the weekend with new features such as the Profile Search, the August HPO Release, as well as updates to our API documentation including a new endpoint for our Medical Action Ontology (MAxO}.

Please let us know of any features you would like in future releases on our tracker, we look forward to your feedback!

Regards,

The HPO Team

August 2020.title: August 2020 Release
August 2020.body:
Hello HPO community,

we have updated the HPO.

See release announcement here.
Regards,

The HPO Team.

June 2020.title: June 2020 Release
June 2020.body:
Hello All,

Hope everyone is staying safe during these hard times. Today we have updated the web application with the most recent release of HPO.

See release announcement here. We will have a new feature soon to find intersecting assocations for your hpo terms of interest.

Regards,

The HPO Team.

March 2020.title: March 2020 release(2) aka the Epilepsome release
March 2020 release
March 2020.body: The HPO team has made a new release of HPO for March 2020 dated 02/27/20 in the obo. Updates to this web application include mapping of rRNA and tRNA genes and minor usability enhancements. Please check our downloads page as the format for annotations has changed! Suggestions and issues for the website can be reported here https://github.com/TheJacksonLaboratory/hpo-web/issues. If you would like to make a new term request please visit https://github.com/obophenotype/human-phenotype-ontology/issues. Any further questions, please don’t hesitate to contact us.

November 2019.title: November 2019 release
November 2019.body:
The HPO team has made a new release of HPO, the disease-annotations, and the gene annotations.
In total we have added 80 new OMIM entries and added over 2000 new disease annotations. Over 1500 terms now have logical definitions assigned to DOSDP patterns, which will further improve HPOs quality and interoperability with other ontologies.

Minor changes include a merge of two HPO terms that represented abnormalities in cartilage morphology and the fixing of multiple typos in textual definitions and synonyms.

If you have further question, please don’t hesitate to contact us.

October 2019.title: HPO Web Application 1.6.0
October 2019.body:
We are happy to announce we have released hpo-web 1.6.0 over the weekend with new features including frequency, onset, and source for HPO terms associated with a disease.

We now have API documentation for those interested in accessing our data via REST API.

Please let us know of any features you would like in future releases on our tracker, we look forward to your feedback!

Regards,

The HPO Team

September 2019.title: September 2019 release
September 2019.body: The HPO team has created a new release for September 2019.

June 2019.body: The HPO team has created a new release for June 2019.

April 2019.title: April 2019 HPO Release
April 2019.body: The HPO team has created a new release of HPO and the disease annotation data. See release announcement here.

April 2019.title: HPO Web Application Release and Ontology Synchronization
April 2019.body:
The HPO Team has a new web release with some upgraded features such as LOINC annotations for terms, a new way to browse related publications, and minor updates to the term hierarchy.

Please let us know of any features you would like in the near future on our issue tracker, we look forward to your feedback!
Regards,

The HPO Team

April 2019.title: LOINC2HPO accepted for publication
April 2019.body: A manuscript that describes our effort in converting LOINC-coded clinical lab tests into HPO terms has been accepted by npj Digital Medicine. The conversion allows one to semantically integrate clinically equivalent lab tests together and aggregate patient phenotypes based on the HPO hierarchy. We demonstrated its applications in generating patient deep phenotyping profiles and biomarker screen with an asthma dataset. For details, refer to the open-access article here.
April 2019.teaserTitle: Converting lab tests into HPO terms

February 2019.title: February 2019 release
February 2019.body: The HPO team has created a new release for February 2019.

December 2018.body: If you are interested in using HPO or MONDO in Microsoft Word, Google Docs, or any other word processing software, please check out Phenotero at the Phenotero Website or read the open-access article here.

December 2018.title: 4000 completed GitHub issues
December 2018.body: The HPO team is grateful for the support we have received from the community over the years. Today, we have closed the 4000th GitHub issue on the HPO GitHub tracker at https://github.com/obophenotype/human-phenotype-ontology/issues. Thanks for the input!

October 2018.title: October 2018 release
October 2018.body:
The HPO team has created a new release for October 2018. Over 120 new classes have been added, and over 150 classes have been obsoleted/replaced. Over 200 new disease entries have been added and thousands of new disease-phenotype associations have been curated.
Best,
Sebastian, on behalf of the HPO consortium

May 2018.title: New HPO Annotation File Format
May 2018.body:
The HPO project is transitioning to a new annotation file format in 2018, and we are requesting comments, suggestions, and other feedback prior to making the switch.
The current annotation format dates back to the early days of the HPO project in 2009 and needed some minor improvements to be able to capture more metadata about the phenotypic abnormalities that characterize disease.
The 2009-present format is described here http://human-phenotype-ontology.github.io/documentation.html#annot
The new 2018-onwards format is described here:
http://hpo-annotation-qc.readthedocs.io/en/latest/annotationFormat.html#new-and-old-big-file-formats

The main differences are

1. The frequency field is now strictly constrained to have one of three formats: HP:0003577 (a term from the frequency subontology) or 12/45 or 22%
2. There is a field that can indicate sex-limited phenotypes
3. There is a field that can be used to record terms from the HPO ClLinical modifier subontology (e.g., 'bilateral' or 'transient')
4. The Aspect field has been updated to reflect the fact that annotations can come out of the subontologies Phenotypic abnormality, Inheritance, Clinical course, or Clinical Modifier.

The new annotation file is located on our Jenkins server and is called phenotype.hpoa.
Feedback on the format is welcome. We also welcome feedback on the question whether the practice of having a separate file for negative (NOT) phenotype annotations should be maintained, since we are considering putting all information in one file (the negative lines have a NOT in column 4 in both new and old formats).

Please contact peter.robinson@jax.org with questions or comments.

May 2018.title: Easy-to-use and secure deep phenotyping
May 2018.body:
Today we would like to inform you about Phenotero.

The rationale behind Phenotero is that in precision medicine, especially in clinical genetics, the Human Phenotype Ontology (HPO) as well as disease ontologies like the Orphanet Rare Disease Ontology (ORDO) or Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) are often used for ‘deep phenotyping’ of patients and coding of clinical diagnoses. This is especially important because it allows for streamlining of clinic workflow and efficient data entry, and will subsequently promote clinical and molecular diagnosis, remove ambiguousness from manuscripts, and enable sharing of anonymised patient phenotype data with ultimate goal of a better understanding of diseases.

However, the process of assigning ontology classes to patient descriptions is often disconnected from the process of writing patient reports or manuscripts in word processing software such as Microsoft Word or LibreOffice. This additional workload and the requirement to install dedicated software may discourage usage of ontologies for parts of the target audience. Retrospectively applied text-mining suffers from inaccuracies, noise, and often privacy constraints.

To improve this situation, we developed Phenotero, a freely available and simple solution to annotate patient phenotypes and diseases at the time of writing clinical reports or manuscripts. We adopt Zotero, a well-established, actively developed citation management software to generate a tool which allows to reference classes from ontologies within clinical reports or manuscripts at the time of writing.



Please contact sebastian.koehler@charite.de with questions or comments.

April 2018.title: Paper on novel annotation model
April 2018.body:
For the interested reader - there is a new paper suggesting an extended annotation model, which can help HPO-based similarity calculations.

It is available via Database (Oxford)

April 2018.title: Nature Genetics Paper on layperson vocabulary
April 2018.body:
In clinical settings, phenotypic abnormalities are often defined using specialized medical terminology, which can be difficult for patients to understand. This so-called terminology-gap can impede participation of patients and families in research projects concerned with the phenotype or natural history of diseases, and can even make it difficult for patients to understand data from their own medical charts.

The HPO Project and the Monarch Initiative have therefore “translated” the terms of the HPO into “plain language”. For instance, the term for Macrocephaly can be translated as Large skull.

This joint project with the Monarch-Initiative, HPO, PCORI, Sanford Medical, and a lot of other contributors on adding layperson synonyms to HPO has now been published in Nature Genetics.

March 2018.title: March 2018 release
March 2018.body:
We published the March 2018 release of HPO and annotation data. Thanks to all contributors. Please continue to give us feedback and suggestions.

Thanks,

The HPO Team

Feburary 2018.title: HPO mailing list for news announcements
Feburary 2018.body:
The HPO team has set up a mailing list, as we feel we can’t reach everybody with posts to our website and/or twitter. Please join the mailing list at https://groups.io/g/human-phenotype-ontology to get the latest news and discussions via mail.

Thanks,

The HPO Team
